Summons are also a thing, but only in specific battles, and work as temporary NPCs you can’ìt control directly, but spend ATB to trigger their abilities instead.Special mention for bosses, which prove elaborate and unique at all times, not to mention challenging and full of interesting mechanics that break the canons of battle, forcing you to get creative. The only critique I would make to bosses is that they won’t allow you to fully go through a well-planned combo if their health goes low enough, thus triggering a cutscene and resetting their status immediately, even while staggered or otherwise incapacitated.Character Management & ProgressionCompleting quests and killing mobs will credit you EXP, AP and SP. Now, these ‘currencies’ of sorts can be used to respectively increase character levels, something that happens automatically, level-up equipped Materia (also automatic) and enhance weapons, since each of them has its own skill tree of passive abilities, and is generally better-suited for different roles. Not only that, but each new weapon comes with a unique signature ability you can ‘master’ and permanently learn as a skill. Think of Materia as swappable abilities you can slot in weapons and accessories, to build your characters for the roles you prefer - only equipped materia will level up, thus unlocking new proprieties or stronger spell versions, so make sure you focus on what you really need as it’s impossible to get everything maxed out in one playthrough, unless you do a hell of a lot of grinding. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2838803345

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Visit our website, Indie Hive[indie-hive.com], to read other interesting reviews and articles.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Good amount of locations to explore, each with its own unique puzzles or quirks. Each room is interesting to unlock and explore… the first time, at least.- Decent replay value thanks to multiple endings and different possible paths to take.- Logical environmental interaction that plays out in a plausible way using the items at hand.- Tremendously unfair death-related mechanics designed to kill in ways you can’t possibly anticipate the first time. This creates ‘filler content’ via backtracking, since the world resets on each death.- Generic storyline, mediocre writing of lore documents. Nothing feels original or interesting at any point, the decent premise devolves into ‘yet another horror’ very quickly.- Obnoxious voiced protagonist, who speaks the same lines endlessly and describes items in a flat, irritating, out-of-place tone that completely ruins the atmosphere.- Poor MKB support. Mouse usage is limited to aiming / looking around, all menus need to be navigated with Arrow Keys or WASD without key rebinding. Unacceptable for a 2022 PC release.- Inability to discard / delete unwanted or useless items: you’ll have to run back at a stash each time, or use an item if possible, to make room.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- Some distortion effects, like film grain or film bands, can’t be turned off.- Enemies can spawn very close to transitions / doors, and become a guaranteed damage source you can’t avoid in time.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 4 hours to get one of the endings. Playtime may vary greatly depending on number of deaths (resets). Replay value is decent: depending on certain actions and the number of deaths you will unlock different endings and situations, however most of the game will remain the same nonetheless.Is it worth buying?No. Not only the price tag of 20€ is rather steep for 4 hours plus additional runs (that will take much less, given your acquired knowledge), but the outlined issues deal a severe blow to any and all enjoyment. Move on to better survival horrors, there’s plenty around.Verdict: BadRating Chart HereA poorly-executed survival horror that relies on annoying mechanics to stretch content, alongside an obnoxious protagonist and a forgettable story.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832333700In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingNaked and terrified, you’ll wake up in a bathtub full of bloodied water. You don’t have the slightest idea of what happened, and now you’re locked in a motel bathroom. After getting your bearings and finding a way out, you’ll soon understand things aren’t alright at all in this decrepit, half-totaled motel, between unearthly screams and horrendous abominations that roam the locales.Most of Oxide is set in a three-story motel under renovation. The horror feeling is kinda there, with most premises being dark, damp, foggy and eerie, as well compounded by an audio compartment that does the job well enough. Too bad this is all ruined by Matt (as in, you) constantly stating “he needs to get out”, or describing events / items with a tone as robotic as a train station’s automated announcer. Some classic ‘cheap jumpscares’ are added to the mix at times, and they fail to impress.Numerous lore documents pertaining to yourself, or other relevant characters, can be found in the furniture, on the ground and generally all over the place. Each of the writers is distinct enough in their tone, however the content itself feels quite clichèd and just doesn’t hook you the right way at any point. “Mad scientist doing crazy experiments” trope? Check! “Guy who lost humanity and now is on a vengeance”? Sure! “Token female character that doesn’t know what the hell to do”? Yep! Horror tropes 101, everyone.Exploration & PuzzlesYour primary goal will be opening as many rooms as you can, in the hopes of finding a way to the third floor’s common areas, the only exit still available. Think of each room as a self-contained mini-puzzle, as most of them will have one or more items to interact with, that often require you figuring out a specific item order, a code, or the right item to use between several. There is always a right way and several wrong ways to get something done, the latter ones often inflicting you a detrimental status effect, or killing you instantly in a few cases.The main issue is that in many instances, not only is there no clear way to figure out what’s right or wrong, but you’ll also be actively deceived by Oxide itself. For example, I found the number “15” behind a closet, and said to myself “that must be the correct vial, among five, i have to pick for this puzzle!” - nope, I got poisoned and died instead. Expect this to happen numerous times, and if you ran out of supplies, well… goodbye!Exploring the premises will indeed net you a modest number of consumables, like bandages or antidotes, vital to clear the effects that otherwise become lethal in around 30-40 seconds or so. Even by collecting all of them, there’ll be no way in Hell you’ll be able to get out alive on your first run: too many shenanigans you can’t predict.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832658783Combat & Inventory ManagementYour trusty revolver will be the only means of defense against the horrors. Bullets are a fairly common finding, and most enemies take five to vanquish. It's a simple point-and-shoot affair, with a small quick time event to free yourself from an enemy’s grab, and no other particular mechanic, since all except one enemy are static threats. It has to be noted enemies have a detection system, some of them can be ‘stealthed’ but this is inconsistent - most will just spawn and target you immediately after certain interactions, though.Up to nine inventory slots can be gained, via some items found in the various rooms. This is very limited compared to the amount of  unique stuff you’ll find (like keys), but the shared stashes alleviate part of the issue by letting you deposit items for later use, and retrieve them at any time. And yet, expect to backtrack back and forth numerous times for this.Death-related MechanicsSo, what happens exactly when you die? Don’t worry, I'll now explain to you the peak of game design we have to deal with here. Upon your demise, a story-related cutscene will play, different each time, and you’ll be back to square one at the bathtub. Everything has been reset: stash, inventory, upgrades, doors are locked again. Some things changed, though: certain enemy spawn have been altered, and on later deaths more foes will spawn, like poison plants. Most item spawns remain the same, except for a very few that change slightly. This would be fine and interesting if implemented properly - not the case here.The thing is, nothing major changes with death, apart from more enemies to deal with and the ending you’ll get. You’ll have to do the exact same things again twice, thrice, etc. - each time with added annoyances. This becomes tedious, boring very soon, and given the game kills you in unpredictable ways as explained before, this creates a perfect storm of frustration. Don’t think of this as ‘old school’ because it isn’t, it’s simply badly designed.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832658863

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Exceptional visuals. Each environment is rich in details, finely crafted and leaves nothing to chance. One of the best visual renditions of 1940s Italy I’ve seen to date.- Historical accuracy. Being Italian born and raised, I can definitely tell the devs did their homework as far as authenticity is concerned.- Good variety of gameplay elements. For a narrative adventure, the type and number of activities to complete is above-average, most feel enjoyable as well.- Zero-censorship policy on the depicted situations. Expect strong themes like extremely crude gore, animal cruelty, child abuse and everything in-between, in line with the wartime setting.- Solid storyline, that has enough pathos to remain captivating and characters believable enough to not result implausible.- Terrible optimization. Framerate drops, occasional stuttering and scorching temperatures will be normal even on high-end machines far above the requirements.- Inconsistent voice acting. Some characters’ way of speaking feels flat, starkly contrasted with the eventual situations of urgency, fear or danger they’re involved in.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- In rare cases, some interactions may get stuck forever. Load a saved game to fix.- Players may end up outside the map in a certain location.- Some secondary choices may not account correctly for consequence in specific cases.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 9 hours to complete Martha is Dead (MiD), taking extra time to clear what secondary content I managed to find, and explore all locations accurately. The content is entirely linear, there’s no reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?The standard price of 30€ (3€ / hour of playtime) is still a bit steep for this amount of content, despite the good quality offered. I’d recommend waiting for a small discount before buying.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereA high-quality narrative adventure with a setting that proves novel, historically-accurate and interesting. Some moderate issues prevent it from realizing its full potential.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830781616In-DepthPremise, Setting & Writing1944. Italy is ravaged by the misery of war, with Allied forces moving up towards the Tuscany region while Axis troops mount a desperate defense. Protagonist Giulia K. is the daughter of a high-profile Nazi officer, but even this privileged position doesn’t save her from tragedy. One day, her twin sister Martha is found dead in a lake - an overwhelming loss. She always was her parents’ favorite, unlike Giulia, so the latter decides to take her identity, pretending to be her from that moment forward, to gain the love so far denied to her.MiD mostly takes place in and around a countryside villa outside the village of San Casciano, Tuscany. There’s a remarkable attention to detail in the realization of each location, from the interiors of a typical upper-class 1940 Italian household, with luxuries such as electric power and a phone line, to the verdant woods and sun-beaten dirt paths commonly seen in the rural areas of the region even today. The marked contrast between these idyllic landscapes and the brutality of war, or the horrifying visions in Giulia’s mind, creates a rollercoaster of varied atmospheres that works out very well.Apart from the protagonist, there’s a small roster of relevant characters that, however, never happen to dialogue directly with you at any point: a consequence of the recent events, and of the pretense Giulia decided to put up. You’ll hear conversations, read missives, listen to telephone calls, but never engage in active dialogues save for some phone calls at specific points. The writing feels plausible, with an Italian voiceover that accounts for the different mannerisms and speech patterns of the time. Most situations feel plausible and realistic, even if (probably by design) you’ll end up questioning the veracity of some of them as the game progresses. Exploration & InvestigationThe story plays out through a number of days, each having a primary objective related to the events at hand, and a series of optional activities as well. Generally, you’ll be able to explore the world freely at any time, with the primary areas being the villa and its courtyard, the nearby forest and the lake. Some places will be locked until specific events happen, or certain quests are triggered by your findings. Your trusty camera will be of paramount importance, as it will not only allow you to collect evidence in order to shed light on your sister’s death, but also to use filters (such as infrared) to reveal the unseen. There are a vast number of interactable objects that reveal more about the family’s past, the general lore or the people related to you in some way, each of them is voice-narrated by Giulia. Those looking to do everything will find much information in these optional interactions, they’re definitely worth the extra time spent.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2831372692Secondary QuestsWhile your focus remains finding the truth about Martha’s death, there will be other things to do as well. For instance, hidden riddles can be found by photographing specific objects in the world, optional points of interest that reveal dark stories, or trigger quests altogether. These missions may be optional, but contain a good chunk of unique content, such as puzzles, minigames and sub-storylines regarding parallel ongoing events. Some of these elements also can be missed, since the game progresses in a series of days alongside the main quest’s evolution: after certain events unfold, some areas may not be accessible anymore, thus locking the quests out forever (unless you reload an earlier save). Going just for the main story is something I wouldn’t recommend, as these secondary missions, even if a tad annoying in pacing at times, prove overall interesting and expand on the narrative considerablyPuzzles & MinigamesThe most frequent type of puzzle will be associated with photography: relevant items to frame, both primary and secondary, will be highlighted on your HUD, and it will be up to you to use the right camera accessories, such as filters, and set the right zoom level, exposure and focus to get the perfect shot. Not only that, but photos also need to be developed in a dark room, which involves a simple button-pressing prompt as QTE. Other than that, you’ll eventually be decoding telegraph ciphers, finding items such as keys to unlock doors, boxes and passages containing critical items, or figure out the right things to say in a phone call to extract information. There are also a few quick-time events here and there, but they’re fairly simple and not demanding in skill or reflexes at all, in line with the genre’s expectations.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830781865

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Some clever combat mechanics that prove interesting to use, give the system uniqueness to an extent.- Wide variety of enemies with unique movesets, quirks and abilities.- Good art direction: each area feels unique and well-constructed visually.- Serious balance issues with weapon classes and builds. Ranged is OP, 2H is just a DPS downgrade compared to anything else, Dual has a horrendous moveset, 1H / Shield is just plain.- Mechanically shallow. Many features customary to the Souls genre are emaciated or downright absent; this makes progression, combat and build-crafting too simplistic.- Story, lore and characters feel insipid and cliched. It never hooks you at any point, leaves a sour aftertaste once the credits roll.- Boring level design, that results way too linear for the genre, with only two “hidden” optional areas in total, and nothing else of interest to find or get excited for at any point.- Disappointing co-op system design: not only does it require random consumable drops to function, but is also restricted to bosses only.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- Unreliable hit detection with certain enemies or weapon move sets.- RTX makes little visual difference in general, and isn’t worth using.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:Took me around 12 hours to clear a run (logged 15h ‘cause I restarted once early on), while taking time to explore all locations accurately. There is some replay value in experimenting with a different build (which isn’t gonna be a totally different experience, unlike in some other Souls), everything else stays the same.Is it worth buying?No. The price of 40€ is way too steep for this amount of content, features and quality -  even discounted, this will always be a mediocre title. There are other sci-fi souls (Surge 1-2, Shattered to name some) much better than this for the same or lower cost.Verdict: MediocreRating Chart HereA subpar attempt at Indie Souls-like. Ultimately DOLMEN feels generic, uninspired, simplistic and devoid of any polishing despite some genuinely interesting ideas. Genre veterans may have some fun with it, but it’s objectively not a good title.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828724614In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingRevion Prime was just another anonymous planet under Zoan control (your faction, by the way), until the powerful DOLMEN Crystals were discovered on it. Some scientists got their hands full, started experimenting with trans-dimensional technology, and made a real mess of things - on top of other factions wanting a slice of the cake. Guess who has to clean up the mess?If the classic trope of “someone fiddled with stuff they couldn’t comprehend and screwed up reality” sounds clichè, that’s because it is. Despite locales actually feeling diverse and reasonably well-designed, at no point the narrative premise evolves past “bash everyone in your way to get the damn crystals” or has any memorable character. We have the power-tripped supervillain, the zero-charm protagonist that says probably five lines in the entire game, the generic utilitarian radio operator, and a slew of NPCs with the personality of a rusted wheelbarrow, that have no quests or backstories whatsoever. Not even the optional lore files salvage it, as they never really prove interesting.ExplorationDOLMEN plays out as a classic souls-like in this part, meaning you’ll be roaming various locales crawling with enemies, look out for the occasional item to collect, and most importantly activate Beacons (bonfires), which allow you to restore HP and Batteries (Estus), but also respawn enemies. Beacons also allow you to fast-travel between each, and teleport to your ship which contains crafting, cosmetic and leveling-up facilities, plus a totally useless NPC that just stands there staring at you menacingly.Don’t expect a complex level layout with exciting secrets and mind-bending verticality or hidden shortcuts: most levels are linear, with just a couple exceptions - most don’t even have any real shortcut or looping design at all. The only reasons to explore are crates with crafting materials, hidden NPCs that grant unique parts and lore files, but that’s all rather easy to find.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828761665Combat System & BossesBread and butter of the experience, the combat here has some good ideas, admittedly. First of all, healing doesn’t work as you may be accustomed to for this genre. Energy (as in, Mana) acts as your healing medium, and can only be recharged with Batteries, coming in limited amounts and restored at Beacons - Estus Flask with extra steps. Mana also is used for Energy Mode, which is an amped-up status you can trigger at any time, that gives elemental powers to your attacks, other than also for ranged weapons and eventual weapon-specific abilities.The way elemental effects are handled is pretty good, as when enemies with one of the three status effects (Frozen, Burning, Poisoned) are hit with a weapon of that same element, this triggers powerful passive effects that deal significant amounts of damage - debuff first, hit second, that’s the way to go. This is a smart system that could have been built upon, but sadly it wasn’t so.Now onto the issues. The main issue with combat is the jank, with fiddly animations and mechanics that are about as reliable as that used car you bought last month from that shady salesman. What is customary in the genre just isn’t there: backstabs, ripostes, spells, stat-boosting consumables - all of this simply isn’t accounted for, making combat feel shallow not after long. The balance is all over the place really, with ranged easily overpowering everything else, alongside a fast melee as side to exploit elemental effects while energy recharges. Boss design feels average at best, with none of the fights really feeling epic despite their evolving movesets and sometimes considerable difficulty.Progression & CraftingEnemies and breakable elements drop crafting materials that can be used at the ship’s printer to craft progressively better weapons and armors, each with stat requirements to be used, of course. Each armor and weapon will contribute towards a certain Technology (Zoan, Driller, Revian) with passive abilities to match, think of it as a ‘set bonus’ of sorts. Crafted items can be further enhanced with Epic and Rare materials which give them better stats compared to the “regular” versions. Unless you want to craft boss weapons, which require you to kill each boss three times (respawning them costs crystals with low drop rate), the rest of the materials will come along without particular grinding in general. You can use Nanites (souls) to improve your character stats permanently in the ship pod, and this works like in any other Souls game.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828036749Multiplayer SystemYou can attempt bosses in jolly cooperation with your fellow DOLMEN players, using a beacon near each arena. The design of this is dement however, as it requires consumable, low-drop resources you can lose on death to be activated, no refunds in case you lose. Whoever thought gating multiplayer behind resource grinding was a good idea, didn’t think straight at all.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Impressive simulation accuracy: physics, vacuum, cutting mechanics and all the hazards are recreated incredibly well; they contribute to a realistic experience.- Good number of ship variants that become increasingly complex and dangerous.- Compelling progression system, with upgrades that consistently feel like a real improvement.- A gameplay system that rewards precision, method, planning ahead and heavily punishes rushing / not learning the mechanics properly.- Above-average soundtrack quality, with some really neat tracks in it.- Clichèd story with largely uninspired characters and boring dialogues. It doesn’t hook you at any point, and has few (if any) gripping moments.- In some phases, it’s unclear what needs to be done to make the main story progress: this can lead to wasted time and some frustration.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- In some cases, the story may not progress at the intended time. Restart the game to fix.- Significant frame rate drops (from 60 to 30-40) on some larger ship models, even on good hardware.- Some materials / components are color coded the wrong way in the scanner.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me 32 hours to complete Hardspace Shipbreaker (HSB) in Standard mode, and also unlock all the achievements. The campaign is linear, without choices, and ship models will start being always the same after a while; I see no reason to keep going after that, since you’ll have seen it all by then. There is no reason to replay, either.Is it worth buying?The 35€ tag is fair for this amount of content and especially quality. I can definitely recommend a full-price purchase.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereA brilliant sci-fi sandbox puzzle that manages to create a fresh gameplay formula. It’s a pity the story can’t be up to par with the other excellent elements.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826400797In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingStory-wise, HSB starts off with a not-so-novel premise: humanity became a space-faring civilization de-facto controlled by megacorporations, with alliances and governments losing more control as time passes. LYNX is the biggest fish of them all, having pioneered modern space travel, thus amassing ludicrous amounts of power and resources. That’s who you’ll be working for as a shipbreaker, tasked with dismantling decommissioned vessels for the recycling market. The game pushes heavily on the themes of ethical treatment of workers and sustainability of employment. Your shipbreaking career will be contourned not only by the stories of your colleagues, each shedding more light on the grim state of humanity and on LYNX’s dehumanizing practices, but also reinforced by dozens of data recordings found in derelict ships. From your cramped living quarters to the overly-lawyered contracts and documents piling up in your inbox, the corporate dystopia seems all too real.Shipbreaking OperationsMost of your time will be spent in the shipyard, pulling apart vessels large and small to net LYNX a big stack of cash, in shifts lasting 15 minutes each (you can dedicate multiple shifts to the same ship, don’t worry). Each ship is made of the most diverse materials and appliances depending on its role (cargo, scientific, military…) but it all boils down to one thing: sorting the right stuff into the right ‘bin’ (either furnace, processor or barge) with most things being color-coded on your scanner for this purpose.You’ll have three tools for this job: the cutter, able to slice through low-density materials, vaporize walls, provide access to sealed compartments: your number one ally in dismantling things correctly. Then you have the ‘gravity gun’, able to move heavy objects for you to push into the right bin, and later on create Tethers, that essentially act as self-pulling ropes to haul ship parts too big for you to handle. The last tool are demo charges, able to cut entire ships in half in a matter of seconds, but at the cost of risking damage to sensitive equipment, explosions, fire hazards - use their power wisely, and only as last resort. The passive scanner highlights objects and sorts them by purpose and color, so that you know what’s what without too much hassle.The amount of perfection in how destruction, physics, explosive decompressions, fires are all recreated is great, even in failure there is some kind of strange pleasure, in seeing a ship blown in literally hundreds of smithereens flying everywhere, or the mess left inside after a decompression gone wrong.If this sounds simple enough, you’ll quickly realize it isn’t. Accidents happen - often: from a small fire burning a couple of cargo crates to a critical reactor meltdown blowing away half a ship, everything demolished or processed incorrectly will be deducted from your already miserable pay, and also make you fail company Salvage Goals (more on them later). You’ll have to learn how to properly disassemble many kinds of engines, machinery, reactors, and deal with mishaps on the fly before they become critical. There are even ships with rogue AIs on them, scrambling the internal systems randomly and making your life hell. Should you die, a heavy fine will be applied, but you’ll respawn without penalties.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826879455Progression SystemDepending on your performance in salvaging, you’ll be credited Rank Points and Lynx Point Upon fulfilling salvage goals, which are milestones in correctly dismantling each ship - of course, more complex or hazardous ships will reward more of them. You may spend LPs to upgrade your initially pretty bad tools, making them more resilient, efficient, or even add new functions to them. Your passive gear can be enhanced as well, for instance sensors can be improved to detect more item types, while your suit can be reinforced to make you withstand even harsher conditions. Once in a while the story itself will go on, unlocking tutorial ships that will illustrate critical game mechanics or teach you how to use a new upgrade - but that’s not always the case: sometimes, especially later on, you’ll have to figure things out on your own. Side Activities & CollectiblesThere are few things to do aside from shipbreaking, and they mostly relate to collecting. Posters found in wrecks can be taken, and used to customize your habitation pod. Stickers, awarded for progression milestones or particularly good performances, can be put onto tools as a cosmetic enhancement, but serve no other purpose. At some point a ‘ship repair’ minigame will come up, allowing you to illegally salvage components that should go to LYNX for your own purposes. Decrypting and listening (or reading) lost data recording can be interesting, as it sheds light on the state of the galaxy, but it will take a huge amount of time to find them all.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826400964Additional Game ModesFree Play allows you to pick from any ship models, everything unlocked, to just have some fun either scrapping it correctly or blowing it to bits - sandbox no-consequence mode. Cutter’s RACE is sort of a time trial where you can compete against the clock to salvage a ship as fast - and as well - as humanly possible.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Excellent, versatile progression system that allows a wide variety of combinations between passive skills, gear types, pets, accessories and unique weapons.- Multiple markedly-different biomes: each has unique resources, enemies, bosses and randomly-generated points of interest.- Enemy invasions, farming, breeding and recruitable survivors give good depth to base building, without turning it into a management headache.- Good organization / quality of life features allow managing resource stockpiles, inventory, crafting and everything else in an efficient way.- Well-designed, multi-phase boss battles that feel like proper milestones once you overcome them, and need some planning to be dealt with.- Several mechanics are poorly-explained. This may cause frustration when they become more prominent.- ‘Tough’ difficulty is nearly-unfeasible in solo later on. Heavy grind for god-rolled gear / clones / rare pets becomes mandatory and terribly dull.- Survival aspects are minimal and easy to overcome. Hunger is hardly ever an issue while sleep, climate, illness, shelter aren’t accounted for.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- Rarely some base guests may wander out, stand in the middle of nowhere and not use the facilities correctly.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 19 hours to complete a run of Keplerth on Standard difficulty (had to restart due to Tough scaling in solo). Given that you can try all builds in a single run and there are no mutually-exclusive factors, linear content, there’s no reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?Yes. The price of 12,50€ is more than fair for this amount of content and quality. I can recommend buying for full price.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereKeplerth delivers a polished, enjoyable open-world ARPG experience, and manages to stand out from the crowd thanks to its original mechanics. Better in co-op.Visit our website, Indie Hive[indie-hive.com], to read other interesting reviews and articles.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2820944226In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingAfter busting out of a cryostasis pod, you find yourself in an abandoned facility with no memories. Soon enough you find a damaged robot that explains some of the recent events, including that his friend, Dr Schip, is building a spacecraft to flee the planet and go back to the civilized systems. The hard-to-obtain materials can only be found in the bowels of the planet - that’s how your cave-crawling, pickaxe-wielding adventure begins.Something went seriously wrong - you can tell that after seeing demolished villages filled with horribly mutated people and abominations. Still, there are also normal folks around, belonging to various fantasy races like Elves, Orcs and so on. You won’t see them defending against the horrors or do anything else than going around, though. In the underground, cramped, dark tunnels filled with all kinds of dangers are the norm. The atmosphere is cartoony and works fine, but lacks boldness most of the time.The story is not elaborate, despite the good number of lore files found in dungeons and facilities as you travel. The attempt made at indirect narration, with a “build-your-own-interpretation” approach works only partially, and you’ll scratch your head about more than a few things. Still, it’s an ARPG, so the story was never a high expectation.Exploration, Progression & CraftingWhile the planet’s surface has a lot going on, like fast-travel portals absent underground, and NPC villages offering items for sale and unique services, most of Keplerth’s world actually expands vertically. Across five biomes, you’ll progressively find better and more plentiful minerals, paired with stronger foes the deeper you get. You can go underground with stairwells that need to be of better materials to pierce the harder ground, effectively preventing you from going too deep too soon.Modifying your genome and crafting better gear are the keys to beat all the horrors waiting for you. Felling plants, digging minerals and killing enemies may drop unique ‘mutated’ materials that can be used, along with T-Energy, to unlock passive skills you can equip, swap anytime in the form of modules. These can be arranged in a limited space, acting as a little Tetris of sorts, and have set bonuses for further specialization. Paired with gear set bonuses or unique properties, re-rollable buffs, the possible build variety becomes quite wide. To do most of that, plenty of materials will be needed: killing enemies, breeding livestock, digging minerals will all be things you need to do, especially later on, to obtain enough rare materials to keep up with crafting requirements - don’t worry, crops and animals mostly take care of themselves once started.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2820300636Combat System & BossesThe combat is rather straightforward. It uses active skills, ranged and melee weapons as means of offense, depending on your build of choice - skills are acquired only later on from Events, and not unlocked by leveling (there’s no leveling at all, or attributes, in fact). Arguably, fights with normal enemies are one of the weakest components: despite the variety of builds, weapons and skills, most of them play out as a simple trade of blows, without dodging, blocking, parrying or any other skill-based mechanic to make the difference and offer more nuance. The same can’t be said for bosses, which keep attention high thanks to various phases, and often spam tons of adds for good measure, too. Once a boss is beaten, the next tech level will be unlocked, although all of them can respawn, and you can fight them to get rare drops from their loot pool. Just don’t attempt Tough difficulty if you go solo - really, the bosses become so spongy, lethal and self-healing, you’ll have to grind the hell out of rolls, skills and companions to even make a dent in them.Base ManagementOther than storing items in chests (that can’t be labeled, which is annoying), your base will be useful for two other things: farming and being a Bed & Breakfast. Yeah that’s right: other than crops and cattle, useful to get ingredients to cook meals, but also gene-altering ingredients and crafting materials, you can also recover people in distress. They’ll live in your base, use the facilities you make for them, and pay you a literal rent. They won’t defend it, obey your commands, and just eat, sleep and bathe in saunas all the time. But those bucks are great, in fact citizens are the best source of income long-term.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2821119940Invasions & EventsIf you enable them, Invasions will happen regularly based on the highest depth you reach. Enemies will build outposts near your base, then attack you periodically, until you manage to demolish their base - they will try to break down doors, enter and make a mess of things, so fending them off becomes a regular nuisance, that however awards materials and items. Event Portals are found a few biomes in, they award currency bundles, unique skills or rare pets with often strong passives - definitely worth it. Random spawns like abandoned facilities, cities and other areas may also happen, often they have their own kinds of enemies and rewards to match, adding more to the exploration part.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Satisfying progression with a plethora of diverse weapons, items, upgrades and accessories to obtain. - Excellent enemy variety, with many of them having unique properties, attacks and powers.- Original vehicle customization mechanics that prove enjoyable, fresh, and unlike anything seen in other JRPGs.- Good amount of interesting optional dialogues and information to reveal more about the world or past events.- Dual-purpose combat system (on foot and with vehicles) contributes to keeping the loop fresh.- Subpar English translation, riddled with bizarre sentences and constructions.- Normal difficulty becomes too easy soon enough (exception made for a few encounters), while Hard is locked behind completing the game.- Multiple gameplay mechanics are poorly explained / displayed, or aren’t at all. The same goes for status effects, enemy HP, item properties and other things.- Dated visuals for a full-on remake, considering the current industry standards.- Character skill trees don’t really feel meaningful, unique or majorly useful at any point.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- No support for any resolution above 1080p.- No keyboard & mouse compatibility, a gamepad is required.- Lack of any graphics settings other than resolution.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me 23 hours to finish Metal Max Xeno Reborn (MMXR) on Standard difficulty, while finishing all the side-content I could find. The content is largely linear: even with a new difficulty and Survival mode (disabled traders / facilities) unlocked afterwards, I see little reason to replay.Is it worth buying?The price of 40€ is a bit steep for this quantity and quality of content. I’d recommend waiting for at least 20% off, unless you’re a hardcore fan of this franchise.Verdict: GoodRating Chart HereAn interesting, enjoyable post-apocalyptic JRPG with several original takes on progression and combat mechanics. Yet, it’s held back by poor translation, technical shenanigans and some less-than-ideal design choices.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2819164034In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingThe incipit of MMXR is hardly novel: mankind created an AI to solve the crippling environmental issues of our planet. It worked quite too well, as it (rightly) concluded humans were the primary issue. In the consequent dystopian world you’ll wear the boots of Talis, one of the few surviving humans, hell-bent on destroying all the machines.Set in the aptly-named Dystokio, MMXR introduces you to a deserted world nearly-devoid of life, save for mutant abominations. The few remaining humans reside at Iron Base, Talis and crew’s main operations center. Between sandy expanses and crumbling bunkers, the post-apo feel is definitely there, but don’t expect an overly-realistic take on it. It’s sad that the visuals aren’t up-to-par with 2022 standards: at times it looks like a PS2 game!The side-characters aiding Talis’ endeavor will have distinct personalities, however don’t expect much elaboration on their backstories, nor great changes of character from them at any point - they’re sufficient sidekicks, nothing more. The lore itself is quite good, however the terrible translation often butchers it, rendering it less enjoyable.ExplorationIs mainly performed using a variety of tanks and armored vehicles, however there are a good amount of sections where you’ll be forced to go on foot, as well. Dystokio is divided into five large sectors that you’ll progressively access as the story goes on - while the game promotes “non-linear open world”, this isn’t true since going too far will get you steamrolled by overpowered foes. Your minimap indicates all loot-crates, digging spots and respawning resource piles, so there won’t be any eye-squinting in the search for loot, which of course becomes better as areas become more advanced. Teleporting back to base and back again is something doable at any time, except during combat; a convenient feature that merges with Fast Travel Points, that act as ‘checkpoints’ of sorts across the five zones. Each square meter is littered with respawning enemies that will attack should you stay in their vision cone long enough - not immediately, so there’s some time to avoid trash encounters if you want.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2819163981Combat SystemIs divided between ‘on foot’ and ‘on vehicles’, both of them using a turn-based mode with an optional auto-attack function that effectively makes it real-time until toggled. In the former, you’ll use Talis plus two sidekicks, and fight across tunnels, buildings, crevasses and whatever place is too narrow to reach by tank. Characters can be equipped with a variety of weapons, melee and ranged, with diverse firing patterns, ranges, AoEs and damage types. This becomes important later on, when many enemies will have specific resistances or weaknesses. Fights are your standard JRPG affair, with turns where you can use items, skills or simply attack. As XP is gathered (only for active party members), you’ll be able to spend Skill Points in one of the six specialization trees, each granting special passive and active abilities.Vehicle combat works in the same way, but with a twist: each tank has Armor instead of HP and won’t be destroyed when that reaches zero, instead Components (engine, cannons, etc.) will start taking damage, eventually disabling the tank completely and forcing the driver to fight on foot (usually a deadly proposition against vehicle-grade foes). Of course going back to base will repair everything, but also field fixing is possible, albeit in a slow way, since each item has a lengthy usage animation. Tanks will progressively become unrealistic, hulking monstrosities with five cannons, somehow operated by a single crewman; up to three can be brought with you on any sortie. Fighting on paper is complex, with many status effects, skills, passives and damage types - while these factors have to be accounted in the harder fights, most of the time simply building your tank platoon properly and setting auto-attack on will clear most scuffles without a hitch.Customization & ProgressionIron Base allows you to craft, improve and purchase a vast array of components and weapons for your crew and vehicles. Better engines will increase your tanks’ maximum weight limit, allowing them to carry heavier, better weaponry and armor without incurring in the heavy HP maluses derived from overweight. There’s no equipment limit, money does all the talking in MMXR and acts sort of like a ‘second XP’: get rich enough via selling, missions and enemy killing (bounties especially), and you’ll quickly get your hands on powerful gear. Individual weapons can as well be modified into 2.0 and 3.0 variants with the right materials, lightened or hardened to be more resilient in exchange for more weight cost, the latter also goes for vehicles. Chips unlock powerful abilities, like attacking with all cannons at the same time instead of one at a time, or perform other special moves, but they’re expensive and need to be installed with a specific strategy in mind, to obtain the best synergy, stack effects.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2819164116

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- Original, well-developed western-steampunk setting that works well and feels dynamic.- Interesting story that, despite some clichés, keeps interest up and is paired with interesting characters.- Decent amount of worthwhile side-quests, optional activities.- Good variety of parts to customize and improve your ship with, including rare or unique ones.- Lackluster roleplaying factor: your choices will ultimately lead to the same events in most cases, while good or bad reputation doesn’t seem to influence anything tangible.- Some annoying quality of life issues, such as absence of equipment comparison, no quick buy / sell, extremely slow world travel speed, inability to skip low-level trash encounters.- The overall challenge level is mild at best: you become powerful pretty soon, while the encountered enemies are often not up to par. No difficulty settings available.- Enormous amount of typos, grammar errors and general writing mishaps in dialogues and descriptions.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- Severe FPS drops may occur when opening the inventory or trading interfaces.- Rarely, some dialogues may not trigger correctly.- Some UI / UX elements may temporarily glitch out, not function or display incorrectly.- F12 brings up a debug interface: reassign the screenshot key to something else.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 25 hours to complete Age of Grit (AoG), and also clear all side-quests I could find. Despite being (wrongly) marketed as a CRPG, the variety of builds and choices is rather limited, its content mostly linear. No reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?Yeah. The default price of 12,50€ is more than fair for this amount and quality of content. Overall, I can recommend buying for full price if you’re interested.Verdict: DecentRating Chart HereAoG is a passable RPG, with its original setting and an interesting story as strong points. It lacks polishing, and is lackluster in some aspects, sure, but not too bad overall for Indie standards.Visit our website, Indie Hive[indie-hive.com], to read other interesting reviews and articles.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2815616728In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingAfter the Great Migration, most of humanity moved to a large continent known only as “The West”, currently under the control of three major factions, hanging in a fragile peace brokered after several bloody conflicts. You’ll play as grizzled war veteran Jeb Rockwell, a no-nonsense hardcore cowboy with a small but skilled crew under his command. Soon enough, a certain event triggers newfound lust for vengeance in Jeb, as he chooses to embark on a journey filled with political intrigue, secrecy and - of course - a good dose of violence.The blend of steampunk and western settings is hardly innovative, however AoG manages to do it right thanks to a solid amount of lore not only about the main cast and events, but also technology, society, history and other aspects - most of which is gained through optional dialogues. Generally, characters and quests have solid writing, with a high amount of exposure and details that contribute in painting a clearer picture of what’s going on, even if at times some aspects may seem implausible or irrational. Exploration & Side ActivitiesDue to finite fuel, your ship will be limited to predetermined routes along the world map, with cities and outposts being ‘dots’ along these imaginary roads - there’s no free-roaming (which is disappointing for an RPG), but there may be random events along the way, such as enemy encounters or discoveries with positive or negative outcomes. Each location can be entered, displaying important characters to speak with, which in turn may give information, assign quests, have stuff to trade, or even challenge Jeb to a duel. Cities serve as ‘hubs’ for character dialogues, essentially, and it’s important to note some of them may evolve or not be available anymore, as days dynamically pass while traveling. The main side-activity will be questing (usually assassination or fetch assignments), of course, although trading comes as a close second: buying low to sell high where a specific good is in higher demand can net good profits, too bad your cargo hold can never be upgraded in size, so this is a relatively low risk but tedious way of making money.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2815616582Combat SystemAlways one-on-one and with simultaneous turns, combat pits ships against each other in aerial duels. Each turn you’ll be able to choose where to spend your steam points (no pun intended…): activate your radar for passive bonuses in evasion, armor penetration and accuracy, rev up the engine to gain more steam next turn (but watch out for overheating), or use it on weapons, enabling them to fire more powerful volleys the more steam is used to juice them up. Most murder tools have special random effects that may influence your or the enemy’s ship, such as setting them on fire, blowing up in your face, or disabling a system, other than their own accuracy rating, steam cost per shot, penetration values. It may seem like a lot of factors to consider, but at the end of the day the best strategy is buffing up, stacking steam for some turns, then unleashing all your weapons on whatever poor sod you’re fighting, usually obliterating them.You get a chance to get some of  your foes’ weapons or gear when you kill them, to then use them or sell them at a city for an extra buck. Combat has a decent system but a lot of features feel under-utilized, it’s not as complex as it seems really, despite the game kinda ‘wanting’ it to be. It doesn’t help that enemy AI isn’t exactly the brightest.Progression SystemYour ship’s gear and weapons represent the only progression you’ll get - there are no skill trees, no passive / active abilities, no traits (that’s why I said the RPG component is lackluster!). As you plow through bandits, military and complete quests, you’ll be able to buy or find better hulls, components, guns and so forth - making you able to withstand more punishment and deal with stronger foes - which does feel rewarding. It’s straightforward, with no limitations as to what you may or may not equip, as long as you have the space for it - no stat requirements or anything such.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2815616470Dialogues & Roleplaying ComponentWhile dialogues are extensive and rather elaborate (despite mostly linear), the same can’t be said about the actual roleplaying. Jeb may choose to deal with situations in one way or another, sure, such as by sparing or killing a character, or solving problems in a more diplomatic manner (often resulting in Karma Tokens being earned), opposite to Infamy Tokens, awarded for actions considered ‘evil’. The metric upon which this is determined is not always the best, as a few times a clearly good action awarded Infamy, and vice-versa, for apparently no reason.What hurts more, perhaps AoG’s worst problem, is that no matter how famous (or infamous) you become, people will react to you in the same way regardless, this won’t bar you from any quest or anything else - as it often is the case in RPG sporting a morality system. The dialogue choices often lead to the same conclusion, and give only a fake sense of choice that isn't really there.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.🟩 Pros🟥 Cons- The good variety of situations throughout the campaign contributes in keeping interest relatively high.- All weapons feel diverse, fun to use and prove useful against specific types of enemies or situations.- Interesting premise and setting, that however aren’t elaborated upon enough.- Reasonably satisfying challenge level on ‘Hard’ difficulty.- Generic clichèd story, dull protagonist and forgettable side characters that don’t hook the player at any point. - Heavily recycled locations through both main and side activities.- Badly-designed backtracking system, that makes collectibles and hidden secondary activities a mind-numbing chore.- Inconsistent graphics put visually-appealing models and textures alongside extremely low-quality ones.- Horrendous control system on Mouse & Keyboard (‘P’ to pick up items? Seriously?!).- Multiplayer is dead: I was unable to try it.🟨 Bugs & Issues🔧 Specs- Key rebinding doesn’t work properly and glitches the controls.- FMV cutscenes are compressed to extremely low quality.- Missing or wrong button prompts while performing specific actions.- Alt-tabbing may cause freezes or crashes.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 16 hours to complete Lost Planet 3 (LP3) on Hard difficulty, while also doing a good number of side-activities (though not all). Given the linear nature of all activities, I see no reason to replay once completed.Is it worth buying?No. This game is nearly ten years old, and only offers mediocre quality; the price of 25€ is totally unwarranted as it is now. You might want to pick it up just to finish the franchise if you’re a fan, on sale (as I did), but generally I’d recommend avoiding it completely to most people.Verdict: MediocreRating Chart HereLP3 is a disappointing conclusion to an already less-than-stellar franchise. Evident porting issues, clichèd story and cheap asset recycling make this one more of a slog than anything else, its redeeming qualities just too weak to drag it out of the pits.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813764042In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingIn a rather plausible future, Earth has acquired interplanetary capabilities, however it also incurred a massive energy crisis as its resources came on the verge of depletion. The solution? T-Energy, a near-miraculous, all-purpose power source found in the bowels of a remote ice ball known as EDN 3. You’ll wear the insulated boots of Jim Payton, an external contractor working for interplanetary megacorp NEVEC, and tasked with acquiring as much of the substance as possible, while fighting against both extreme conditions and the dangerous local fauna.LP3’s setting is realized rather well, as it manages to convey great desolation and sense of loss with the stalagmite-ridden, storm-ravaged areas of the planet. The struggle of NEVEC’s teams against nearly-untameable forces of nature and the deadly Akrid is portrayed well, as it is the profit-oriented corporate mindset that prevails above all else. At times, mostly through rundown facilities and damp caves, LP3 also deviates to a more ‘horror-like’ atmosphere and does so decently well.Despite such potential and premise, all the characters that encompass Jim’s adventures, up to and including himself, prove unremarkable. An insipid protagonist is put side-by-side with ‘textbook antagonistic underdog’, cheerful ‘notice me senpai’ youngster trying to shine, ‘tired boss’ and more clichèd characters from start to end. The story is rarely interesting, as it uses the already tired ‘humans shouldn’t meddle with what they don’t understand’ trope to produce a mediocre plot that feels stale, already-seen after just a couple hours.General GameplayBeing a corporate contractor, your job will be executing various tasks from your superiors, which act as main missions. Your faithful RIG - an industrial bipedal robot as tall as a house - will be a vital asset to accomplish the job, as it’s equipped with utility tools that double as weapons. LP3 alternates RIG-driving phases with much more common on-foot sections, where the careful explorers will be rewarded, as there’re T-energy (currency) drops hidden around, lore-related material and Specialized Components, vital to upgrade your RIG with new, better functions.While the main activity is fighting Akrid hordes, there’s a bit of simple platforming, some puzzle-solving and exploring thrown in the mix, to give some much-needed variety to the loop. While this is an appreciable effort, the extremely limited roster of locations will weigh down heavily as you pass the same place, with the same enemies, for the 5th time in a row to do some side-quest. Generally you’ll unlock more weapons, upgrades and RIG enhancements as the main story progresses, although some of these are tied to secondary quests or even collectible-fetching.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813763927Combat SystemJim will carry two primary weapons with limited ammo, and the classic ‘infinite pistol’ as sidearm, plus a couple very powerful grenades. Almost anywhere, EDN 3 is crawling with Akrid of diverse shapes and sizes - each with different abilities and attack patterns. All weapons have some sort of specialty target, for instance the sniper rifle will be great against single, armored targets but near useless versus hordes - special ammo that drastically alters how each gun functions is a thing, too, but can’t be refilled by normal ammo drops to offset its power. Generally, fighting Akrid involves well-timed dodges, taking cover from ranged attacks, and hitting the glowing weak spots to inflict major damage, although some fights (especially bosses) may have unique mechanics unto themselves, that however rarely prove truly exciting or fresh - actually, they mostly prove clunky, half-assed garbage.RIG combat sees Jim using his mech to deal punishment to the enemies, despite it not being a military vehicle. A 10-ton drill to the head will instantly kill most smaller enemies, and deal massive damage to larger ones - given that their weak spots are exposed. A system of quick-time prompts to trigger counter-attacks and special moves exists when fighting most ‘big guys’, however I found that using the RIG is generally a downgrade compared to going down and dealing with them on foot as your weapons, united with Jim’s agility, are just better than the RIG’s.Character Progression & Side ContentUsing the T-energy awarded from missions and kills, Jim will not only be able to upgrade his tools, but also acquire new ones alongside unique upgrades tied to the completion of specific side-quests. While the character doesn’t directly evolve, his equipment will. For instance, finding the rare Albino Tarkaas specimen will enable purchasing permanent passive skills, while extracting samples for the base’s chief scientist will unlock special ammo. These side-missions, while sometimes worthy in terms of rewards, prove extremely boring, slow and dull due to the overall pacing riddled with transitions, loading times and useless waiting: trust me, you will get bored of such chores long before the end of it all.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813840508

Захватывающая сказочная история. По-моему это единственная игра в данном жанре из всех что я знаю, которая просто лучше всех передает сказочную атмосферу. В этой игре прекрасно всё, геймплей, повествование, сам фантастический мир проработан до мельчайших деталей и крайне красив, саундтрек, ох, какой же тут приятный саундтрек:))

Очень красивая, трогательная, интересная и захватывающая история, сильно цепляющая за душу. Как и первая часть Life is Strange, Before the Storm вызвала у меня бурю эмоций, заставив лить слезы в конце (да и не только в конце), будто я девочка обсмотревшаяся второсортных сериальчиков про любовь... Только здесь всё иначе, ни одна история не переплюнет эту...  В игре очень много правильных мыслей и идей. Здесь крайне интригующее повествование, оторваться практически невозможно, а пройдя её, хочется вернуться! Игра 10/10, настоятельно рекомендую её всем всем всем!!!

Что могу сказать, это первая игра в моей жизни, которую я прошёл за один присест, без перерывов, еды и воды...У меня такого кома в горле не было никогда в жизни, ели сдерживал слезы...На сколько сильно я упал в осадок словами не передать... Такая душераздирающая история о взрослении человека, как личности, стремлении добиваться своих целей и умении нести ответственность за свои действия, просто потрясающеLife is Strange - отныне и навеки моя самая любимая игра и история...это лучшее что когда либо придумало человечествоТакие правильные мысли, возможность делать тот или иной выбор и отвечать за последствия, которые просто пугают и ты понимаешь, что даже в игре умея оборачивать время вспять, уже ничего не исправить, не то что в жизни. 1000/10Square Enix, спасибо вам!!!

Очень грустная и трогательная история одного человека, который не может понять, по тому ли пути он пошёл по жизни, который вспоминает ошибки прошлого и переживает о том, что многое делал не правильно или о том, что не успел сделать...В игре очень приятная атмосфера, потрясающий саундтрек, красивые пейзажи, идеально для того, чтобы зарядиться приятными эмоциями на пару дней, жаль только, что проходится она за пару часов, а так всем советую, не пожалеете)

Никогда, НИКОГДА НИКОГДА И ЕЩЁ РАЗ НИКОГДА, не обарачивайтесь назад!!!!!!!!!!! Если не хотите провести следующие 15-20 минут сидя на унитазе с корвалолом...Игра нереально атмосферная, для меня, как для любителя хорроров, сильно страшная, видимо давно не играл в ужастики. Понравились нововведения по сравнению с первой частью, графон, оптимизация, сюжет очень интригующий уже с первых минут. Всем советую, игрулька топ!

Игра просто космос. Интересный сюжет. Потрясающе красиво проработанный игровой мир, очень сильная атмосфера доисторических времен, аж 10.000 лет до н.э. Это время в этой игре переданно очень правдоподобно. Ведь что может быть лучше, чем неторопливая прогулка по густому лесу под захватывающим дух млечном пути, наслаждение окружающими тебя звуками, да и в целом той самой чистой, не тронутой человеком природы, которой так не хватает в нашем современном мире... Игра заслуживает своего внимания однозначно, может она и не лучшая в серии Far Cry по мнению многих, но мне она всё же понравилась больше, чем предыдущие части. Игру однозначно рекомендую!
Самый топовый хоррор из всех, в которые я когда либо играл! Сюжет очень интригующий и захватывающий, атмосфера очень таинственная и страшная, так и хочется идти всё дальше и дальше во тьму. 10\10

Читал комментарии к игре. Люди писали, что в процессе прохождения они все сидели охрипшими, я подумал: хрень какая-то. Итак я начал играть, по началу всё казалось слишком просто, но потом я дошёл до первого монстра, я человек очень эмоциональный, поэтому я визжал как девчонка, а заклинания так и не хотели работать, после 5-10 попыток произношения нужного  мне заклинания я уже не выдежрживал и кричал: Tial мать твою с*ка бл*ть Udah, и всё заработало:) 10 Tial udah из 10:))

Игра крайне красивая, очень захватывающая и интересная. Настолько красивого и проработанного подводного мира я не видел ни в одной игре, и не увижу. Крайне интересный сюжет, музыкальное сопровождение стоит на уровне с музыкой из Assassins's creed или The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt (то есть, божественное!) В ABZU хочется играть и играть, ради этого шедевра хочется купить 4ка монитор, чтобы насладиться по полной программе. Очень приятно исследовать подводный мир, взаимодействовать со всеми рыбами, китами, акулами и т.д. Всем кто любит получать удовольствие и полный душевный расслабон, покупайте и играйте. Минус один: игра довольно короткая, 5 часов на то чтобы пройти игру 2 раза полностью. Жду продолжения!

First release in 2020 for the PS4. Reinterpretation of the PS1 classic that only shows the first 8-hours of Final Fantasy VII and stretch into a 33-hours game. The real problem is that they made structure and story changes that destroyed the magic of the original. If you haven't played FFVII before, I recommend the 1997 version first. Note: The review is based on my Final Fantasy VII Remake playthrough on PS4 and a replay the the original FFVII (PS4 port - Midgar Part) in 2020. ⠀⠀⠀⠀My curator page⠀⠀⠀⠀

First release 2004 in Japan on PC. Start of the Trails in the Sky Trilogy. Classic turn-based JRPG with elements similar to the Materia system in Final Fantasy VII. Be aware of the slow pacing at the beginning.⠀⠀⠀⠀My curator page⠀⠀⠀⠀

Another FromSoftware masterpiece which takes the „Dark Souls DNA“ and put it into an Action-adventure game.Positive(1) Great soundtrack especially at bossfights(2) Fast loading times(3) HDR support(4) Great visuals(5) Fixed difficulty setting (6) Very demanding Bossfights but never unfair (7) Native Xbox One Controller support. DUALSHOCK 4 also supported(8) Good enemy placement(9) Perfectly balanced progression system so you can't be overpowered(10) Superb fast combat and satisfying parry mechanic(11) Good level design but doesn't come up to the class of Dark Souls 1(12) Replayability because of New Game+ and different endings (new bosses)Negative(1) 60 fps lock(2) No ultrawide native support (only via mods)(3) Only one default main weapon and armorMY REVIEW SETUP:

First released in 1995 for the SNES and designed by the "Dream Team" Hironobu Sakaguchi (creator of Square's Final Fantasy series), Yuji  Horii (creator of Enix's Dragon Quest series) and Akira  Toriyama (creator of the Dragonball mangas). The Steam version is based on the mobile port. I played it for the first time in 2018 and it's amazing how well this game has aged. For me its: Still one of the best JRPG ever made.Positive Straight forward time travel story with great pacing and no filler Replayability because of different endings Active Time Battle (ATM) System with NO separate fighting screen and random encounters Superb soundtrack (composed by Yasunori Mitsuda and Nobuo Uematsu) Original graphic mode: "Similar to the original pixel art"  Fixed difficulty setting Native 16:9 support 4:3 support, to play it in fullscreen you have to change the system resolution to 4:3 Native Xbox One Controller support. DUALSHOCK 4 also supported Negative Modified mobile User Interface. No original SNES UI Partly custom controller binding. You could only change X, Y, B and A buttons The onscreen conroller buttons only shows the Xbox layout MY REVIEW SETUP: i7-6700K | 32 GB DDR4 | GTX 1080 FE | HDD install | Win 10 Pro |

Самая необычная mmorpg, что я видел. Сейчас обьясню почему:1) необычно-быстрая прокачка для жанра2) необычный для многопользовательской игры жанр. Это не просто mmo, это некое подобие diablo, только без изометрии и с донатом.3) Донот, слабо влияющий на игру ( что достаточно редко встречается)4) Приятная графика, музыка и отличная физика, да еще и при низках системных требованиях!5) Интересный геймплей, множество способностей и возможностей для билдовНо как бы ни печально это было, в этой игре есть и минусы:1) Очень навязчивый донат. Он хоть и не влияет на баланс, но он просто везде! Все можно купить! И тебе будут напоминать это еще и еще.2) Слабенький сюжет. За ним просто не интересно наблюдать. Он банален, хоть в основе и стоит великая D&D. 3) Много скучных квестов а-ля убей-принеси или зачисти данж и убей боссаВывод: Это неплохая игра, но честно говоря ее вытягивает только геймплей.

This is a very unique game with lots of features such as picking up items, climbing walls and the ability to change character at any time. The main character is a little girl named "Mary" and she fell asleep in a wardrobe after hiding from her parents arguing and now when she wakes up she discorvers that she is in an magical world full of giant strawberries and magical druids!. She has a friend called "Aquarius" and togheter they walk around in this world solving puzzles and quests trying to find a way back to the real world. It got great graphics.Pros:The game is cheap and you can get trading cards. The graphics are amazing The music is greatThe physics are 10/10The controls are easy to get used toCons: There is no menu or tutorial

What an awesome new way to experience Portal!Playing with the element of time, where what you do in the past affect the future, but what you do in the future does not affect the past. Kinda obvious but spooky when put into practical use.The levels could be very challenging if the concept isn't entirely understood, which makes it all the more fun and exciting to solve.I hope for new levels and more content like this!Community content taken to an official level, awesome stuff!

It was not mentioned that co-op is only with random people.Can't get a refund as I waited over 2 weeks to play with a friend.The game itself is amazing and I was very hyped towards the experience, but this weird decision to make it co-op only with strangers - makes it more a singleplayer game than an "online co-op" game.

I have no idea how, but it's even better than DOOM 2016.Epic carnage, blood, gore, weapons. Fast paced action all around.Story really gives you a reason to want to push through the hordes and move forward.A bunch of collectables with a great map that helps finding the general direction of the hidden item, but still leaving the search to the player.Saving is very limited, very specific auto-save checkpoints and end of missions.Forced me to leave the game open when I had to leave yet didn't want to lose progress.But whatever.All around a great experience, worth my money.

Very challenging but with the dedication that is required comes great satisfaction and fun.Dark Souls in Japanese, Katanas, Kiminos and other elements that indicate Asian culture.I loved the challenge and the thrill of facing an impossible boss again, and again, and again; and finally becoming so good you destroy that boss in a great attempt.Spent my weekends playing this while off the army, enjoyed the struggle and travel around the game.
Great fun, satisfying and fun with friends. Could be challenging at times, but youtube is always there to help you out. Great price. No regret in playing a mobile game on my GTX1080ti.

It might be short, but size doesn't matter. (Right?)An amazing experience, just diving into this world and exploring it, the way everything's done, satisfying, high quality.I'm not a game reviewer but I definitely should've played this earlier.What an amazing ride.

What an interesting experience!I very much enjoyed the beautiful sountrack the game has, the pixel art is simplistic and beatifully done!The actions you do and the way the world responds to you is often satisfying, ecouraging you to not procrastinate!The gameplay is simple: Build smart enough to protect what makes you coins so that you may either conquer the land and leave to the next or just leave to the next one. That's my way of seeing it ignoring the road getting to your purpose.The challenge of the game for me is in two things:1. Earning coins: It's not simple to establish a good source of coins, as you get attacked and caught off guard at times which destroys all your work, and rebuilding deep into the game is suicide as you will encounter more enemies as the days go by.2. NPC speed: The builders you hire and command, the beggers you give coin and reason to walk to your town, all WALK so SLOWLY!!! I can't count the amount of times I saw a begger I payed die because he walked so slowly towards the town.DAYS will pass by the time far away builders will finally come to your position and get what you need done. Of course they can die easily if you didn't plan ahead their position when the enemy's horde pummels through your walls.These 2 incredible challenges made me too frustrated to continue playing normally, so I get a Cheat Engie table for some "boosters" as god mode, infinitie coins, archers that shoot more arrows a second than there are trees in the entire game, and so on.To summerize:The game is made beautifully made and is challenging!So prepare yourself for some tough times, but maybe you'll like the struggle. The beautiful sountrack and design will help you through it all, so have at it at your own risk.The price is fair, so don't wait for a sale and support these great developers!

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ what a ride!You might think that 13 hours is little, but every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minute was fun.(I only finished the story, got lots of fun maps to explore with my friends!)Gameplay wise, it's too much fun.The variety of weapons and their uses, their mods and upgrades, makes it all awesome fun.Lots of blood and crazy animations. Movement is pretty simple for the most of it.The powerups that you can find are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AWESOME!The maps are full of interesting things to find and explore, adding more to the killings you do endlessly.Story wise, it's pretty good.While it's not Witcher 3-36-possible-endings-GOTY-tear-spawning-heart-crushing-love-making story,It's good enough to give you purpose and some things to think about. The characters are interesting and each with their own ideas and ♥♥♥♥ whatever I like killing stuff.Personally it felt a bit slow at the start, but it was probably just to get new players used to the game.To summerize,It's an experience every gamer who thinks he likes FPS should try,an experience every gamer who thinks he likes to kill should try,an experience every gamer who thinks he like to have fun should try.Truely, a masterpiece.TL;DRSTOP WASTING YOUR TIME READING THIS AND ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BUY IT IT'S ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AWESOME

I'll never be able to describe the experience as a whole in words, the story and gameplay is just too much.The DLCs are amazing, price feels just right for the amount of content they add.I find this a very enjoyable game, beatifully made and written.Fighting is interesting although simple, the riddles are too much fun to solve,roaming the beautiful maps is amazing, listening to the music is exciting,and finishing the game is heartbreaking..I wish I had a meme or something to finish the review, but this game is worthy of much than that.I leave my heart here. The feelings the game awoke in me reside in this review.Feast on them, and know what a real game can make you feel.

Awesome gameplay, a damn shame it's peer2peer connection, dedicated servers would've made this a 5/5 trumps.I gives this 3 trumps out of five, damn connection is annoying when people are continents away from you.

Streets Of Kamurocho jest tytułem na który się zajarałem od razu gdy o nim usłyszałemPo zdjęciach można zauważyć, że będzie to typowa gierka rodem z tych automatów co często są nad morzem... Wybierasz sobie postać i po prostu przechodzisz z poziomu na poziom, a jak giniesz to gra się kończy i wszystko musisz zacząć od początku... Nie myliłem się, ponieważ naprawdę tak jest.Jednak, osobiście nie uważam, że jest to jakiś wielki minus, w sumie to podoba mi się taki system, za parę złych ruchów płacisz, a kara boli bardziej im dalej dojdziesz.W skrócie, nie liczcie, że spędzicie w tym wiele godzin, jest to gierka raczej na jeden, maks dwa wieczory... Jednak, naprawdę warto sprawdzić ten tytuł, zwłaszcza teraz gdy jest za darmo.

The Stick of Truth pierwsza z dwóch gier powiązanych z South Parkiem, i śmiało mogę przyznać, że Kijek Prawdy jest lepszy od The Fractured But Whole.Największym minusem gry jest krótka fabuła, jeśli komuś naprawdę się śpieszy to będzie w stanie przejść tą grę w 6-7 godzin.Jednak pomimo tego, gra nie ma żadnych większych wad, przechodząc fabułę po raz pierwszy, czułem się jakbym oglądał jakiś dłuższy specjalny odcinek South Parka.Pierdzenie na swoich przeciwników oczywiście na plus

Tak szczerze, nie spodziewałem się, że Brawlhalla to będzie tytuł który wciągnie mnie na dłużej niż dwie godziny.To była jedna z tych gier typu: Nie wiem w co sobie pograć więc pobiorę sobie pierwszą lepszą free gierkę.Brawlhalla to naprawdę dobra gra, i co najważniejsze nie ma w niej żadnego Pay 2 WinNa postacie możemy uzbierać sami po prostu grając, a skiny można sobie kupić jak ktoś chcę, taki dodatek dla większych fanów.Gra ma jednak jeden spory minus.Niektóre postacie są po prostu broken, przez co gdy widzę Oriona mam ochotę wyrzucić  klawiaturę przez okno.Gdyby postacie typu Orion zostały usunięte to gra byłaby idealna, jednak przez tą mechaniczną za przeproszeniem (słowo na K) daję 8/10Pozdrawiam cieplutko
Po wydaniu wersji 1.2.4 śmiało mogę polecić tą grę.Trzeba przyznać że wygląda ona zdecydowanie lepiej niż poprzednie częścidodanie osiągnięć na plus!
według mnie obowiązkowa gra dla każdego fana wrestlingujest zdecydowanie lepsza niż wszystkie części gier WWE wydane przez 2K

Po około dwóch godzinach śmiało mogę stwierdzić że Kind Words nie jest zwykłą grą, chociaż w sumie jest to bardziej aplikacja niż gra.Kind Words to niesamowita oraz oryginalna aplikacja w której piszemy listy, możemy śmiało wyżalić się co leży nam na sercu, a dostarczane są one przez słodkiego jelonka.Możemy również odpisywać na listy nieznajomym nam graczy, aby napisać im coś miłego lub dać im jakąś poradę.Sama idea stworzenia tej gry jest wholesome, a mianowicie tym czymś jest troska o zdrowie psychicznie innych.Z własnych przeżyć wiem że czasami strasznie ciężko jest wyznać coś osobie którą znamy w prawdziwym życiu.Jeśli ktoś uzna nasz list za pomocny, to nagradza nas naklejką.Kind Words nie posiada żadnych osiągnięć, ale za to posiada coś czego inne gry najprawdopodobniej nie są w stanie nam dać.Świadomość że po przeczytaniu naszego listu na twarzy osoby czytającej może pojawić się uśmiech, oraz jest spora szansa że chociaż w jakiś sposób udało się komuś umilić dzień.

Katana ZERO wydana przez Devolver Digital, studio jest dobrze znane z takich produkcji jak:- "Enter The Gungeon"- "Gris"- "Hotline Miami"- "Hotline Miami 2 Wrong Number"Wszystkie podane wyżej tytuły były według mnie grami strasznie dobrymi, z tego głównie powodu zainteresowałem się Katana ZERO.Plusy:- Strasznie małe wymagania sprzętowe- Niesamowity soundtrack, który śmiało można przesłuchać w wolnym czasie- Gra ma niesamowity klimat, lecz do tego Devolver zdążyło już nas przyzwyczaić w swoich poprzednich wydanych grach- Prześliczny pixel-art- Niesamowita chora fabuła w której nie wiemy co się dzieję od początku aż do końca.( - ) Osobiście uważam że wysoki poziom trudności jest ogromnym plusem, lubie wyzwania, i jeśli ktoś również lubi to zdecydowanie będzie zadowolony.MinusyNajprawdopodobniej jedynym minusem tej gry jest fakt że fabułe można przejść w maksymalnie 5-6 godzin.Chociaż da się to zrozumieć, twórcy zamiast pójść w ilość poszli w jakość, i wyszło im to bardzo dobrze.Ocena ogólnaKatana ZERO jest niesamowitą grą, niestety grą strasznie krótką.9,5/10
